mainmatter.p: Fix a language \mathcal {L} and a cardinal \kappa. An \mathcal {L}-structure, \mathcal {M}, is \kappa-homogeneous if, given any A \subseteq \mathcal {M} with |A| < \kappa and an elementary map f:A \rightarrow \mathcal {M}, for any b \in \mathcal {M}, there is an elementary map f_b: A \cup \{ b \} \rightarrow \mathcal {M} such that f_b|_A = f.

If \mathcal {M} is \kappa-homogeneous, then we can observe by a recursive construction that whenever B \subseteq \mathcal {M} has |B|< \kappa the elementary map f extends to an elementary map f_B: A \cup B \rightarrow \mathcal {M}.
